properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected. Daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius with humidex values in the mid to high thirties are forecast to begin tomorrow and last through Friday. Overnight low temperatures in the upper teens are also expected during this period, unlike tonight which will be a bit cooler. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T18:32:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T02:33:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4155810485.2020

properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected. Daytime high temperatures in the low thirties will continue through the end of the week. Overnight low temperatures near 18 degrees Celsius will provide little relief from the heat. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather will continue through the rest of this week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected this week. Overnight lows near 20 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. A slightly cooler airmass may move into the area this weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty and the conditions may persist for a few areas into Saturday. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T00:29:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T08:30:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3306540243.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat wave continues. A warm and humid air mass over Southern Quebec will persist over the next few days. The heat wave will continue north of Montreal. Temperatures will exceed the 30-degree mark during the day and will not fall below 18 degrees at night. Combined values of the temperature and the humidity will give a humidex value of 40. These conditions are likely to persist into Saturday. During times of high heat, your health and the health of your family and friends can deteriorate rapidly. The ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux du Québec, in cooperation with Environment and Climate Change Canada, recommends that you protect yourself from the effects of the heat by taking the following actions: Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water per day. As appropriate, follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; Avoid alcoholic beverages; Spend at least 2 hours a day in an air conditioned or cool place; Take at least one cool shower or bath per day, or cool your skin several times per day with wet towels; Limit physical activity; Wear light clothes. Be sure to: Never leave a child or a baby alone in a vehicle or a poorly ventilated room, even for a few minutes; Check on your loved ones, especially those who are vulnerable or living alone. If you have any questions regarding your health, call Info-Santé by dialing 8-1-1 or ask a health care provider. In case of emergency, call 9-1-1. For more information, visit the Government of Quebec's Portail santé mieux-être at www.sante.gouv.qc.ca. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T00:28:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T08:29:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3179035361.2020
Area: Gatineau

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A band of heavy rain with embedded thundershowers has stalled over parts of the Annapolis, Kings and Hants counties and is producing locally very heavy rates of rainfall in excess of 15 mm per hour. This band of rain could linger for a few more hours before weakening and moving southward, and over these areas local amounts in excess of 50 mm are possible. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T10:13:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T03:15:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3517597135.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather continues. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected. Overnight lows near 20 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. A slightly cooler airmass may move into the area this weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty. A few areas towards eastern Ontario are likely to experience extreme heat and high humidex values on Saturday as well. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather will continue through the rest of this week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 31 degrees Celsius, with humidex values near forty, are expected. Overnight lows near or in excess of 21 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. A slightly cooler airmass with showers may move into the area late Friday or on the weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event continues through the end of the week. Daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius with humidex values in the mid thirties are forecast over the next several days. Overnight low temperatures in the upper teens are also expected during this period. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and torrential rain. Storm spotters have reported nickle hail_size hail near kelowna ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Bands of heavy rain continue to circle around a disturbance over western Saskatchewan. Over the past 24 hours North Battleford has already seen approximately 150 mm of rain while other communities in the area have seen anywhere from 50 to 100 mm. The rain is expected to gradually taper off tonight but a further 10 to 30 mm may be possible before ending. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-09T14:08:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T01:35:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1579321332.2020
